text:
Hey friends!

I’m getting a ton of emails from folks wanting to write guest posts for our blog (for free). In the past, I haven’t even had time to think about it, but lately I’ve been reconsidering my position.

Typically, they come from people who aren’t in our industry or aren’t even tangentially related. But when someone says they want to write something for free for us with consideration for some keywords we want to rank for, I’m like hmmm.. what’s the catch?

So friends who accept or reject these guest post requests: what _is_ the catch? Am I missing huge opportunities by not seriously considering these kinds of posts? Or am I rightly avoiding headaches and low quality content messes?

attachments.text: Local Wisdom was founded in 1999 by 4 Rutgers computer scientists huddled in a basement. Today, we’re a team of a couple dozen designers, coders, writers, sports fans, pet lovers, gamers, and musicians in the artists’ haven of Lambertville, NJ. We’re fueled by our French press and get fired up by the latest tech news.  ... Read more

text: It's certainly a good opportunity but you should have a process in place to filter out cruft from gems.

elements.text: It's certainly a good opportunity but you should have a process in place to filter out cruft from gems.

text: Most of them are trash lol

elements.text: Most of them are trash lol

text:
in my experience most guest posts that are pitched from other companies are self-serving. they very, very loosely link their article to your industry/target market and it sticks out when compared to the rest ofyour content (not in a good way)

The best guest post pitches i’ve seen are ones that either a) come from a close collaboration with a partner brand or b) things that you request from another brand (e.g. hey, why don’t you write a guest post for us)

elements.text:

text:
To expand on my comment above:

In general, they're just backlink plays — the people who are offering are just doing it to get links back to their site or their clients' sites. Something I often found was that even though these people would offer a post that would rank for a certain topic, the keyword intent for the keywords they'd be offering wouldn't end up matching up with the intent of their post, so it wouldn't end up being any use.

As Shahid said, I'd consider it only if the author sends over quality examples in your industry or works at a company that you're familiar with (and might want to swap guest posts with yourself in order to build visibility and/or backlinks).

I also put together a guest post quality checklist and sent it over to the person prior to them sending me anything to ensure I could reject it if it didn't match up with my guidelines, as well as asking them to submit an outline prior to the draft so that I could approve it or offer additional suggestions on what to include. These two things covered me in the times when I didn't want to accept a post because it didn't work with the standards I held for our blog.

tl;dr - most of the time guest posts aren't great, but if you do decide to accept some, make sure you have clear quality guidelines so you can reject posts that don't match up with them and are setting expectations prior to the post.

text:
Hey <@UJ420S7MG> we are in the same boat. But over time I have been able to put a method to the madness.
1. Look at the guest post outreach email and see if this will make sense for you in the long-term. Of course the intent for guest posts is usually to get backlinks but if you'll closely evaluate you WILL find genuine partners who are ready to align themselves/find unique angles that resonate with you business. Win-win for everyone. 
2. Invest time in crafting solid guest blogging guidelines +voice and tone guidelines and share them with the partners. Ask them to submit a framework (you can create one specific for your blog too) post that. This way you'll be on top of what's coming your way. 
3. Be ruthless—if it doesn't make sense it doesn't make sense. 
4. If you are happy with their writing capabilities, structure a framework for them. This has been revolutionary for us. You get the best writing for free without having to spend hours into editing it or aligning it to keywords etc. 
Hope this helps!

Invest time in crafting solid guest blogging guidelines +voice and tone guidelines and share them with the partners. Ask them to submit a framework (you can create one specific for your blog too) post that. This way you'll be on top of what's coming your way.
Be ruthless—if it doesn't make sense it doesn't make sense.

If you are happy with their writing capabilities, structure a framework for them. This has been revolutionary for us. You get the best writing for free without having to spend hours into editing it or aligning it to keywords etc.
Hope this helps!

text:
Hey all!

My boss has been encouraging me to focus on "practical leadership" instead of "thought leadership." That means basically focusing on actionable content instead of just explanatory content.

But here's where I'm getting lost - This half, we want to focus on driving the audience from being problem aware to solution aware (so more MOFU). And I am having a hard time thinking of anything practical we could talk about here. "Practical leadership" feels like a better fit for TOFU or for a prospect who would be migrating to your solution. Like "x ways to get members engaged" and we weave in our solution (TOFU), or we say "x ways to increase engagement in your community (prospect who would be migrating). I think ideally I'd like to focus more on customer stories for this stage in the funnel, etc.
 
Gut check, am I thinking about it right? What types of content would you suggest?

Like "x ways to get members engaged" and we weave in our solution (TOFU), or we say "x ways to increase engagement in your community (prospect who would be migrating). I think ideally I'd like to focus more on customer stories for this stage in the funnel, etc.
 
Gut check, am I thinking about it right? What types of content would you suggest?

text:
Labels like "practical leadership" "thought leadership" "problem aware" "solution aware" make me cringe. As if the components of how a person interacts with words can be shuffled into these siloed categories of cause-effect and optimized within an inch of their lives.

Find you funnel leak, and get insights directly from the people that fell out or are close proxies to the kind of people that fell out. Leave label town behind and talk to your customers—ask them what they need, what would help when they're making MOFU-esque decisions (sounds like evaluation stage of the classic cust journey).

If it drives conversions, no one will (or at least, no one should) give a shit if the output came from a "practical leadership" angle or not :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
<@UMQASRN1W>! “how to” content tailored to high level executive goals is a solution here.

Like this: <https://www.mavenwave.com/blog/the-future-now-of-retail-3-tips-to-outlast-our-present-moment/|https://www.mavenwave.com/blog/the-future-now-of-retail-3-tips-to-outlast-our-present-moment/>

Address a problem that people know or don’t know that they have, with a larger degree of separation from the product. 

Possible themes include digital ecosystems, transformation, customer loyalty — my “trick” is to identify topics with a clear through-line to revenue.

Lmk if you wanna talk further.
